U.S. Culture Through the Lens of Borat

How a decidedly absurd movie offers valuable insights into our culture

Jackie Thornhill
Mar 31

To one of the roughly billion people in the world living in a state of abject poverty, lacking access to the necessary food to meet their minimum daily caloric needs, the words ‘U.S. culture’ might conjure fantastical images of wealth, success, and unlimited opportunity.

Alternately, citizens of Germany, a nation that abhors the notion of debt so deeply many of their big box stores do not even take credit, might not regard U.S. culture as the best thing given our tendency toward instant gratification and reckless financial spending.

Numerous and extreme as their respective variations may be, the one constant throughout common perceptions of U.S. culture is that it leaves little room for nuance, often relying on the assumption that any one particular subculture can be highlighted and assumed to be ‘truly’ American.

In a May, 2000 LA Times article, “Picturing American Women Through the Eyes of the World’s ‘Baywatch’ Fans,” travel writer Susan Spano warns of the danger inherent in this assumption when it comes to how men see women.

Spano writes, “if men far and wide learn most of what they know about American women from watching shows like “Baywatch” (which features an elite corps of male and female lifeguards who swim like dolphins and look like pinups), misunderstandings about who we are and what we want when we travel are bound to occur.”

In reality, the common denominator undergirding U.S. culture is the pluralistic nature of our society, where people have the autonomy to craft their own representations of culture in terms of what it means to them on an individual level.

There simply is no single, definitive U.S. lifestyle or culture. As a result, those who attempt to claim a monopoly on U.S. culture do so at the risk of alienating fellow citizens whose conceptions might differ from their own.

Former Republican Presidential candidate Ted Cruz learned this the hard way after developing a habit of deriding “New York values” as overly liberal and materialistic, while campaigning in states other than New York.

Of course the divisive phrase came back to bite Cruz when he inevitably had to campaign in the New York Republican primary, as anyone with a calendar could have predicted.

As he rolled into the Bronx to campaign, the junior Senator from Texas was met with angry hecklers and protestors, some of whom had to be forcibly removed from a campaign event by police. The next day the cover of the New York Daily News featured a photo of Cruz and his wife and read, “Honey, how do we get out of the Bronx? Take the F U train, Ted.”

While it may be true that Texas and New York are different places whose populations have different ideas about what U.S. culture consists of in the aggregate, to describe one state as inherently more ‘American’ than the other is simply un-American.

Our culture is not defined by some specific set of values ascribed to one state, city, or community, it’s a mutual understanding amongst the entire population that everyone’s own definition of culture is equally valid. The nature of U.S. culture is that all 325 million-plus U.S. residents could have their own version of it, and each would be equally valid so long as it acknowledged the legitimacy of others.

Further, it is misleading to assume that because the majority of people living in any particular city or state subscribe to overlapping popular conceptions of their culture, the notion of U.S. culture is somehow representative of all individuals within a city or state.

While Cruz cost himself any chance at winning the primary the first time he sneered “New York values” on talk radio, that didn’t stop over 100,000 New Yorkers from voting for him. Therefore, there must be at least some residents of New York whose idea of U.S. culture runs against the grain.

Perhaps the best case-in-point for demonstrating the diversity of U.S. culture is the 2006 film “Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan” written and produced by comedian Sacha Baron Cohen.

Although it can be difficult for some to see past the offensive, often vulgar comedy employed by Cohen, he does a remarkable job of sampling a diverse array of cultures in the film.

The film’s main character and namesake is a fictional journalist from Kazakhstan who embarks on a spontaneous cross country journey in pursuit of Pamela Anderson.

Serving as a case-in-point for Spano’s fear about how Baywatch could influence foreign men’s perspective on American women, Borat impulsively abandons his planned schedule for his time in the U.S. after watching Baywatch on the television in his hotel all night and deciding that he must marry CJ, the character played by Anderson.

Describing her, Borat says, “this CJ was like no Kazakh woman I’d ever seen. She had golden hairs [sic], teeth as white as pearls…for the first time in my lifes [sic], I was in love.”

Through his journey across the country to capture her in a “marriage sack,” Cohen uses the quirky, clueless, and often downright bigoted character Borat to catch Americans off guard, offering an unvarnished glimpse into the lives of a diverse cross-section of people, each of whom understands U.S. culture differently.

Beginning his journey in New York, Borat quickly receives a jarring introduction to the city’s culture, learning the hard lessons about New Yorkers that anyone who has spent some time in the city will pick up on.

Juxtaposed against the small, made-up Kazakh town he’s used to, these people seem remarkably rude, busy, antisocial, and prone to violent outbursts. The next day, Borat implores his producer Azamat, “we need to leave New York to find the real America — rodeos, cowboys, it will be better for our documentary.”

Although his true intention merely to fabricate a post-hoc explanation for wanting to pursue Pamela Anderson, Borat actually stumbles upon a valuable insight, one that is undoubtedly intentional on Cohen’s part.

Though the initial scenes in New York City were certainly laugh-worthy, there is no way the film would have felt nearly as complete or earned the acclaim that it did had Cohen actually filmed the whole thing in New York instead of meticulously structuring it to represent as much of the U.S. as possible.

After departing New York, a stop in Washington D.C. to attend a pride parade and troll some GOP Congressmen provides Borat with a brief introduction to LGBT culture and U.S. politics.

A master of doublespeak, Cohen describes the city as “Washington D.C., home of mighty U.S. warlord Premier Bush,” a statement that appears facetious when spoken by Borat yet qualifies as political commentary on behalf of Cohen.

Then at a rodeo in Virginia, Borat receives a jarring introductory course to Islamaphobia and American exceptionalism, courtesy of the Rodeo’s general manager who makes small talk by advising him, “Of course, every picture that we get back from the terrorists or anything else, the Muslims, they look like you.”

“Shave that dag-gone mustache off so you’re not so conspicuous, so you look like maybe an Italian or something as far as people lookin’ at you. I see a lot of people and then I wonder there’s a dag-gone Muslim, I wonder what kind of bomb he’s got strapped to him. And you probably aren’t a Muslim.”

The shocked expression that threatened to overcome Cohen’s face for a brief, almost imperceptible moment when the Rodeo manager told him to “shave that dag-gone mustache off” showed that even he had surprised himself with the level of raw xenophobia he’d managed to uncover. Masterfully returning to character before allowing himself to react, Cohen played along, acting confused and offering, “I am Kazakh, I follow the hawk.”

Sensing that his racism was being perceived as well-intentioned advice, the manager took it a step further, saying, “but you look like one of them. This thing [war in Iraq] gets over with, and when we win it and kick the butts over there — and all of them son of a butts hangin’ from the gallows, by that time you will have proven yourself and they’ll understand, you’ll be accepted.”

Difficult as the rodeo managers’ remarks may be to digest, they are emblematic of a very real demon that lurks in America’s national consciousness, and one of several breadcrumbs sprinkled throughout the film that in hindsight, help glean an understanding of how Donald Trump was elected President.

Ever since almost three-thousand Americans lost their lives on September 11, 2001, the boogeyman of the Islamic terrorist has loomed large over out nation’s psyche — almost tempting a demagogue to come along and seize on the dread exhibited by fearful, ignorant people like the rodeo manager.

The thing is, men like him aren’t expressing a new idea. U.S. history is largely a story of successive waves of immigrants from Irish to Italians, Jews, Chinese, South Americans, and countless others, having to overcome crippling institutional and social prejudices for decades before being fully assimilated into U.S. culture.

Hateful as he may come across, the rodeo manager thinks he has good intentions and is simply advising Borat of his place in the long history of immigrants who need to “prove themselves” before being accepted. Of course he lacked historical context, failing to realize that this was not WWII, Bush wasn’t Roosevelt, and the military conflicts against ‘Islamic extremists’ in the Middle East would never really come to an end.

In what has become perhaps the most famous scene of the film, Borat proceeds to take the mic at the rodeo, tasked with singing the national anthem, and hypes up the clueless crowd by yelling, “we support your war of terror!”

Pushing to see just how much these people had been desensitized by the regime of “mighty warlord Premier Bush,” Borat continued, “May the U. S. and [sic] A kill every single terrorist! May George Bush drink the blood of every single man, woman, and child of Iraq!” to which the audience hooted and hollered, cheering on the apparently America loving foreigner.

But cheers turned to jeers as Cohen took the patriotic audience for a ride and pulled an abrupt about-face, touching the third rail of their American exceptionalism. Barely able to make it a few verses into his made-up Kazakh national anthem that praised Kazakhstan as “the greatest country in the world” and asserted that “all other countries are run by little girls”, sung to the tune of the U.S. national anthem, Borat was quickly booed out of the rodeo.

Ultimately, his experience there represented a slice of “real America,” highlighting the paradoxically friendly nature and cult-like white nationalism that persist in much of the bible-belt.

In an abrupt change of venue that highlights the many variations of U.S. culture, the next scene shows Borat wandering into a neighborhood of Atlanta, Georgia marked by a “Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard” street sign.

Approaching a group of young African-American men hanging out on a concrete stoop, he breaks the ice by saying, “you look like, uh, Michael Jackson beat it,” which the group appears to find funny. After introducing himself, he asks, “I like you peoples, can you teach me how to dress? How can I be like you?”

The young men proceed to teach Borat how to talk like a walk, talk, and sag like a gangster, a skill-set that he proceeds to contrast with the ambiance of a five-star hotel. Strolling into the lobby with his pants below his butt, Borat tells the frightened concierge, “what’s up with it vanilla face?”

“Me and my homie Azamat just parked our slab outside, we’re looking for somewhere to post up our black asses for the night. So bang-bang, skeet-skeet, nigga, we’re just a couple of pimps, no hoes.”

Needless to say, Borat doesn’t get a place to stay at the hotel, though he succeeds at juxtaposing two extremely different slices of U.S. culture, highlighting the tension between time.

At the “Magnolia Mansion Dining Society” Borat works with an etiquette coach to learn the proper decorum of high-society in the U.S. With Cohen taking things to his usual extremes, he uncovers an impressive form of nearly impenetrable southern hospitality.

The coach tried hard to remain calm as she gently informs him that he might not want to show naked pictures of his son at dinner and advises him on the granular details of how to wipe himself after using the restroom.

When Borat leaves the table she remarks, “I think the cultural differences are vast, but he’s a delightful young man and it wouldn’t take very much time for him to really become Americanized.”

Of course Borat never stops until he’s crossed every line, and the breaking point for this white bourgeois Southern woman proves to be his decision to invite a hooker to dinner. After introducing the table to “my friend Luenell,” Borat is promptly escorted outside and informed that the sheriffs have been called, ending his evening with the dining society.

At one point along his journey, Borat encounters a recreational vehicle full of intoxicated, white male fraternity members who invite him to party with them.

The scene defies the old adage that “society progresses one funeral at a time” by highlighting the shocking bigotry of the students, who ask, “Are women your slaves in old Russia?” to which Cohen sees an opportunity and, answering a question with a question asks, “No, do you have slaves here?”

Suddenly, he has struck gold, as the drunk student replies, “we wish! We wish!” and Borat egged him on, “it is a shame!” The student continued, “Big shame. It would be a better country; we should have slaves.” His friends chimed in with, “Our country, the minorities actually have more power — anyone that is minority has the uh, upper hand, the Jews, anyone who’s against the mainstream.”

Again, by acting completely clueless and enticing real Americans to tell him their true feelings, Cohen uncovers an ugly truth about U.S. culture. As our nation undergoes a tectonic demographic shift, which will almost certainly see the U.S. become majority-minority in the next decade, those who have benefited from institutional inequalities lash out in increasingly dramatic fashion.

Simply put, when you are accustomed to privilege, equality feels like oppression. Hence, young white men, by far the most privileged group in U.S. society, adopt a mentality of victimhood and decide that the world must be against them.

Ultimately, Borat’s journey is a perfect case-in-point for Spano’s argument that reducing U.S. culture to a projection of popular culture isn’t just disingenuous, it devalues the rich array of local traditions and tendencies that actually make up the country’s collective consciousness.

He thought he was going to go to New York and learn about America there before becoming fixated on a Hollywood icon, which helped him realize that the only way he could really understand ‘U.S. culture’ was by traveling across the country to experience it himself.

Just as Spano writes that she has “come to think of it as my responsibility to travel conscientiously and take with me the culture of Nashville or North Dakota” wherever she goes, by traveling conscientiously Borat learns about the variety of distinct cultures that make up America, and gain a truly three-dimensional understanding of the country.
